However, little is known about the boundary conditions that promote upward counterfactuals that enable attitude and behaviour change, rather than downward comparisons that justify the status quo (Fitzgibbon & Murayama, 2022). Future research might thus investigate these boundary conditions to better understand how dissonance may drive behaviour change via counterfactuals.

In addition, the AC/DC model elucidates another pathway that explains why dissonance has been linked to behaviour change in recent research considering the interrelations between ambivalent choices and dissonant commitments. This becomes evident in research on the hypocrisy paradigm in which it has been argued that behaviour change is especially attractive if people believe their actions are hypocritical (Stone & Fernandez, 2008). That is, people experience dissonance due to hypocritical behaviour, for example, if they publicly support a behaviour such as the use of condoms, recycling, or safe driving and are then reminded that they do not engage in the according behaviour (e.g., Fointiat, 2004;Fried & Aronson, 1995;Stone et al., 1994). Such dissonance arguably triggers aversive arousal (Fried & Aronson, 1995), prompting behaviour change because this is seen as more viable than going back on a public endorsement. However, it may be argued that hypocritical behaviours may inherently involve ambivalence from the outset (MacDonald & Hynie, 2008;Ojala, 2008;Taubman -Ben-Ari, 2008): After advocating for behaviour and being reminded of past failures to engage in it, people might become aware of the inconsistency within their attitude or between a desired and their actual attitude, promoting the accessibility or formation of inconsistent evaluations. Therefore, we argue some effects of dissonance on behavioural change can be driven by felt ambivalence.

That is, people experience felt ambivalence when having to decide again whether to engage in hypocritical behaviour after being reminded of their past failures to do so, which, in turn, leads to behaviour change. This demonstrates how a deeper understanding of pre-and post-decisional conflicts provided within the AC/DC model may stipulate novel perspectives on when and why people will adapt their cognitions rather than their behaviour and vice versa to cope with cognitive conflict.

div.head: Paving the Way for Practical Implications
div.p: Due to an enhanced understanding of the intertemporal dynamics of conflict within decision-making, the AC/DC model has the potential to offer various practical implications. In fact, the knowledge of how people cope with cognitive conflict can be used to motivate people to engage or refrain from conflicted behaviours, such as exercising or eating meat, to promote mental and physical health or environmental conservation (Bastian, 2019;Cooper & Feldman, 2020). For instance, research on meat consumption has shown that a promising approach to motivating behaviour change involves counteracting coping attempts that would align people's attitudes with their commitments (Buttlar, Rothe, et al., 2021). To extend such findings and investigate the intertemporal dynamics of conflict, decisions about ambivalent food, such as meat, seem particularly well-suited. To this end, a recent experience sampling study has shown that meat-related conflicts fluctuate within daily life due to ambivalence and dissonance before and after decision-making (Pauer, Rutjens, et al., 2024). Such innovative research designs can be leveraged to investigate the assertions in the AC/DC model. For instance, researchers might test how problem-focused instead of emotion-focused coping strategies affect conflict magnitude and frequency in singular and repeated decisions. This empirical evidence may inspire designing interventions that leverage theorizing on cognitive conflict to motivate behaviour change.

div.head: Positionality Statement
div.p: While research on cognitive conflict has been conducted predominantly in the global north, this review does not bear exception. In fact, all authors who contributed to this review were socialized in Western Europe, although they have diverse socio-economic backgrounds. Shaped by Western cultural norms and educational experiences, this work is inevitably influenced by a lens that prioritizes individual agency and analytical reasoning. Moreover, all authors of this paper were socialized in labs known for their research on (implicit and explicit) attitudes. Thus, our research on cognitive conflict has often focused on ambivalence, even though all authors also conducted several research projects on cognitive dissonance. Of course, we aimed to mitigate potential biases that come with our socialization and pre-existing beliefs (Nickerson, 1998), aiming to provide a comprehensive account of cognitive conflict. Therefore, we tried to avoid selectively choosing or interpreting studies in a biased manner and instead consider cognitive conflict equally through a lens of ambivalence and dissonance. Nevertheless, it is impossible to entirely overcome these biases, which might have led us to give more weight to research that aligns with our attitudinal perspective on cognitive conflicts. Thus, we encourage reflection and engagement with diverse perspectives to enrich our understanding of cognitive conflict.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Dissonance and ambivalence frameworks explain why people experience conflict and how they cope with it-but the intricate relations between these cognitive conflicts are rarely discussed. Drawing on the notion that ambivalence is a pre-decisional conflict while dissonance is a post-decisional conflict (de Liver et al., 2007;van Harreveld, van der Pligt, et al., 2009), we offer an integrated perspective on how people experience conflict within ambivalent choices and dissonant commitments. In specific, we propose the AC/DC model illustrating how ambivalence and dissonance are intertwined and affect each other throughout decision-making. Although many of the described interrelations between pre-and post-decisional cognitive conflicts have yet to be tested, we believe that making the tacit assumptions within ambivalence and dissonance research about their sequence in decision-making explicit offers various new perspectives. In fact, our integration of ambivalence and dissonance frameworks provides testable hypotheses about the relationship between pre-and post-decisional conflict and offers several theoretical implications. It also offers the potential to provide practical implications, for example, regarding behaviour change and maintenance. This way, we hope to pave the way and give new directions for a long-standing yet continuously dynamic field of research.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Note. The AC/DC model posits that imminent decisions ignite cognitive conflicts within decision-making. The dotted lines refer to the impact of the respective effects of problem-and emotion-focused coping strategies on the accessibility of conflicts before and after decisions within singular and sequential decision-making. The asterisk (*) refers to the fact that when people are not faced with an ambivalent decision, they are less likely to perceive their commitment as conflicted and experience dissonance (but see footnote 2).

figure.figDesc: While problem-focused coping could help to resolve conflict over time, it may also explain how conflict manifests. Specifically, problem-focused coping can have heterogeneous effects on people's attitudes if they fluctuate in their decisions about an attitude object and/or when they back down from their commitment. In fact, people do not always make the same choice within repeated decisions based on an ambivalent attitude(Conner et al., 2021;Conner & Armitage, 2008), and evaluative spreads that result from repeated problem-focused coping can cancel each other out across time. For example, suppose people seek information in support of one stance during an ambivalent choice. In that case, they may (perhaps even unintentionally) reverse the corresponding attitude change in a subsequent situation by seeking information that opposes that stance but supports another aspect of the ambivalent attitude. In a similar vein, dissonance-induced problem-focused coping may result in changes in commitment based on counterfactual thinking, and the resulting attitude changes might counteract previous attitude changes that helped people make the commitment in the first place. While such fluctuations facilitate navigating conflict within a singular decision effectively, they could hamper reconciling the underlying inconsistency and thereby give rise to re-experiencing the conflict in the future.

body.note: While it is presumed that cognitive conflicts elicit discomfort when people become aware of them(McGregor et al., 2019;Newby-Clark et al., 2002), the coping strategies that help to deal with these conflicts may either be implicit, explicit or both and people might not be consciously aware of how they resolve their conflicts(Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020).

People with a univalent attitude might also experience felt ambivalence within decisions. This may, for instance, happen during decision-making if they anticipate that there might be inconsistent evaluations about an attitude object, that other people have different opinions about an attitude object, or that there are more desirable attitudes towards an attitude object(DeMarree et al., 2014;Priester et al., 2007;Priester & Petty, 2001).

This does not imply that people cannot experience dissonance based on a univalent attitude without an ambivalent choice. For example, people can experience dissonance in a variety of situations, such as when they hold a negative attitude but commit to act against it in induced-compliance paradigms(Brehm, 1960), or when they hold a positive attitude but later find out that their attitude was incorrect after committing to an effortful behaviour in effort-justification paradigms(Aronson & Mills, 1959).
When decisions are time-sensitive, decision delay might also result in commitments by default. We elaborate more on this in the general discussion in the section "Conflict by Default".
